name: sfchronicle
text:
SF’s historic Japantown has had its fair share of struggle, surviving earthquakes, internment, displacement. 

Now it faces another battle: #COVID19. https://t.co/68DX3yJRv9

name: sfchronicle
text:

Here's the full report: https://t.co/0vqU5CGPvV https://t.co/RGKVqGv8ee

name: sfchronicle
text:
Faced with the worst financial crisis in its 48-year history, BART staff scrambled to put together a $915 million budget for next year. 

Officials have settled on a plan they call “balanced but precarious”: https://t.co/EUahm3pVy3

name: sfchronicle
text: “Bonds has done it again! Deep into right field and way back over the screen, and the kids are chasing that one here at the ’Stick.” https://t.co/xzd6qYfGhT https://t.co/sTGAvG8Nz2

name: sfchronicle
text:
Gov. Gavin Newsom and other state elected officials and legislators won’t be getting a raise this year. The pay freeze leaves Newsom’s annual salary at $209,747.
https://t.co/Ldqp48zMM5

name: sfchronicle
text:
“She was a game-changer.” 

Barbara Babcock, a pioneering legal voice in women’s rights and criminal defense who became @Stanford’s first female law professor 48 years ago, has died at age 81. https://t.co/LwGWMIUk8W

name: sfchronicle
text: Spring training in San Francisco? It could happen, thanks to Mayor @LondonBreed's new order. https://t.co/qiMm1hsRtH

text: JUST IN: The number of California health care workers who have died due to the #coronavirus increased by five to 56 through Wednesday. https://t.co/9FKVtIhiko

name: sfchronicle
text: LIVE UPDATES: One additional person has died due to the #coronavirus in Solano County. The county has reported 22 deaths and 509 total cases of the virus. https://t.co/85o0kWO5m7

name: sfchronicle
text:
Most of the Bay Area is refusing to go along with Gov. Newsom's accelerated pace for reopening. A handful of local health officers have criticized his plan as overly risky, especially with COVID-19 case counts still climbing.

https://t.co/LUAFMK0eKh

name: sfchronicle
text:
Five people were slightly injured this week when a tree shed a branch at San Francisco’s Washington Square Park. A day later, it happened again — this time no injuries.
https://t.co/jYgal9Wsj2

name: sfchronicle
text: Cities and counties can’t charge people seeking police body camera videos and other electronic records for the costs of finding and deleting confidential material, state Supreme Court rules. https://t.co/x6SWx0sDap

name: sfchronicle
text:
Many camps in the Bay Area are allowed to open in June. But that doesn't mean it's going to be easy to find a spot for your kids. 

We list some of the programs opening in-person and online: https://t.co/HCEV7tI4s2

name: sfchronicle
text:
Bad news is coming at — and from — the A’s by the trainload.

@scottostler's column: https://t.co/Bu5eJk3gDp

text:

name: sfchronicle
text:
President Trump’s executive action aimed at social media companies like Twitter isn’t so much about Twitter. 

It is about getting re-elected. https://t.co/ruvrQ46HtJ

name: sfchronicle
text: A blistering city audit found that the Oakland Police Commission has not completed several city charter requirements, lacks organizational structure and may wield too much power in its ability to fire the police chief. https://t.co/DfS4bNNdoI

name: sfchronicle
text:
Next week, the A’s will cease paying many people responsible for their past successes as well as the players who represent the team’s future.
https://t.co/zwuiyqp4e9

name: sfchronicle
text:
President Trump’s executive order aimed at big tech companies isn’t about policy, writes @JoeGarofoli. 

It’s about politics.
https://t.co/hsWQMh503G

name: sfchronicle
text:
People in San Francisco must wear a face covering outside their homes under a new health order, including when:

• Exercising within 30 ft. of someone
• Walking past someone on a sidewalk 
• Preparing food, other items for sale/distribution to people
https://t.co/FHiB9T9wyK

name: sfchronicle
text:
For Game 3 of "Golden Greats: The I-5 Series," we head to Dodgers Stadium. Can NorCal take a commanding 3-0 series lead? Or will SoCal get the win at home?

text: Live or work in SF? You are required to wear face coverings any time you leave home and get within 30 feet of anyone not living in your household. https://t.co/xfkH5K95Lh

text: A pair of Northern California legislators are betting that legalizing sports wagers will help the state's economy recover from the economic shutdown. https://t.co/kYw9ppAZUG

name: sfchronicle
text:

Barry Bonds had his second multi-homer game to give NorCal a 2-0 lead over SoCal in our simulated best-of-seven series. https://t.co/vDtn7s7EL0 https://t.co/VGXH5jdNOA

name: sfchronicle
text:
Many A’s fans dreamed that this season would be a tipping point for their beloved ballclub.

So far the season has been a tipping point, but the wrong way, writes @scottostler. https://t.co/6mrYoRHE2l

name: sfchronicle
text: A majority of BART’s board directors signaled they support the budget that agency staff presented Thursday, which requires a few painful cuts but also relies heavily on federal economic relief. https://t.co/YQgOYBwJXX

name: sfchronicle
text: As the coronavirus continues to make grocery shopping uncomfortable, farm boxes have emerged as a great way to get fresh produce, support local farmers, and avoid human contact. https://t.co/zrspPDc37d

name: sfchronicle
text:
When Madison Bumgarner and Will Smith both left as free agents in the fall the critics pounced, arguing the @SFGiants let them go for nothing.

Rarely has “nothing” meant so much to a team. https://t.co/7jGFadBrGg

name: sfchronicle
text:
As everyone tries to figure out the convoluted rules for Bay Area wineries under each reopening stage, one question keeps coming up:

Why are tasting room reopenings tied to food service? @Esther_Mobley has the answer. https://t.co/MVbeQzsCYQ

name: sfchronicle
text: Sonoma County Sheriff Mark Essick said he will stop enforcing the county’s shelter-in-place order on June 1 because he believes the past and current orders put “significant restrictions on our freedoms.” https://t.co/9TkK76mJA1

name: sfchronicle
text:

His is the latest success story stemming from a new SF public defender unit focused solely on post-conviction relief. https://t.co/xAvUE4evDY

text:
Q: SF released a timeline for reopening. But what does it mean for when you should see family and friends?

A: Guidance around personal interactions — like social visits, dinner parties and play dates — is forthcoming, according to city officials. https://t.co/DVdxmaN71I
